questions.text: Five clean practices under the strategy for elimination of neonatal tetanus include all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "Five Cleans" focus on preventing cord contamination during and after delivery-clean airway is not one of them.

  • Neonatal tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani spores contaminating the umbilical stump during delivery or in the postnatal period.
  • The WHO-recommended "Five Clean" practices are essential to prevent this:
    • Clean surface for delivery
    • Clean the hands of the birth attendant
    • Clean cord cutting with sterile/new blade
    • Clean cord tie (sterile thread or clamp)
    • Clean cord care post-delivery
  • These steps are implemented under maternal and newborn health programs to achieve the global elimination target of neonatal tetanus.
  • "Clean airway" is relevant in neonatal resuscitation, not in the tetanus elimination protocol.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6886002/

choices.text: Mother and infant to be together for 24 hours a day
Initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours in a normal delivery
Giving no food or drink other than breast milk

questions.text: A healthy term newborn is delivered vaginally without complications. The pediatric resident is reviewing hospital policies for supporting breastfeeding in line with the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). Which of the following practices is NOT part of the BFHI guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BFHI recommends initiating breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth, not 4 hours.

  • The Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI), launched by WHO and UNICEF, promotes practices that protect, promote, and support breastfeeding.
  • One of its core recommendations is to initiate breastfeeding within the first hour after birth, which facilitates early bonding, stimulates milk production, and provides the newborn with colostrum, rich in antibodies.
  • Delaying initiation to 4 hours, as in option B, is against these guidelines.
  • Other key practices include rooming-in (keeping mother and baby together 24 hours a day), exclusive breastfeeding without supplementary food or drink unless medically indicated, and feeding on demand rather than on a fixed schedule.

questions.text: World Breastfeeding Week is celebrated in which month?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

World Breastfeeding Week is observed annually from 1st to 7th August.

  • World Breastfeeding Week (August 1-7) is a global awareness campaign led by WABA in collaboration with partner agencies to promote, protect, and support breastfeeding.
  • The week highlights the importance of early initiation, exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months, and continued breastfeeding with appropriate complementary feeding up to two years or beyond.
  • It also advocates for family and workplace-friendly policies that enable mothers to start and continue breastfeeding.

questions.text: The Mother-Friendly Childbirth Initiative was launched in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mother-Friendly Childbirth Initiative was launched in the USA in 1996 to promote safe, respectful, and family-centered maternity care.

  • The Mother-Friendly Childbirth Initiative (MFCI) was introduced by the Coalition for Improving Maternity Services (CIMS) in the USA in 1996.
  • It provides a framework for hospitals and birth centers to ensure that maternity care is evidence-based, avoids unnecessary interventions, and respects the physical, emotional, and social needs of the mother and family.
  • The initiative promotes practices such as informed consent, freedom of movement during labor, non-supine birthing positions, early initiation of breastfeeding, and continuous support during labor.
  • While India has its maternal health programs like Janani Suraksha Yojana and La-Qshya, the MFCI was not launched here. (Option A ruled out)
  • The UK has NICE guidelines for maternity care, but did not launch the MFCI. (Option B ruled out)
  • Australia supports woman-centered maternity care, but is not the origin country for MFCI. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Emphasis on management of sick neonates over sick older children
Treatment is aimed at more than one disease at a time

questions.text: IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) differs from IMCI (Integrated Management of Childhood Illness) in all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both IMNCI and IMCI address multiple diseases simultaneously, so this is not a differentiating feature.

  • IMCI is a WHO/UNICEF strategy focusing on children up to 5 years of age, targeting major childhood illnesses like pneumonia, diarrhea, measles, and malnutrition.
  • IMNCI is the Indian adaptation, developed to address India-specific priorities.
  • The major differences are:
    • Inclusion of neonates (0 7 days) to tackle high neonatal mortality.
    • Inclusion of malaria and anemia as major child health problems in India.
    • Greater emphasis on management of sick young infants, given that neonatal mortality forms a large share of under-5 deaths in India.
  • Treatment for more than one disease at a time is a common principle to both IMCI and IMNCI, and hence is not a distinguishing feature.

questions.text: IMCI (Integrated Management of Childhood Illness) was developed to prevent morbidity and mortality from all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

IMCI focuses on illnesses in children up to 5 years, but does not specifically target neonatal tetanus, which is covered under maternal and neonatal tetanus elimination programs.

  • The IMCI strategy by WHO/UNICEF targets the most common causes of under-5 morbidity and mortality globally:
    • Pneumonia
    • Diarrhea
    • Malaria
    • Measles
    • Malnutrition
  • It also covers other prevalent childhood conditions such as ear infections (otitis media) and anemia.
  • Neonatal tetanus is excluded from IMCI because its prevention requires interventions during pregnancy and childbirth; hence, it is addressed under the Maternal and Neonatal Tetanus Elimination Program rather than child illness management protocols.

choices.text: WHO Growth Standards (Mother and Child Protection Card)

questions.text: An Anganwadi worker in India is monitoring the growth of children under her care. Which type of growth chart is used under the ICDS program for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anganwadi workers use WHO growth standards incorporated in the Mother and Child Protection (MCP) Card under the ICDS program for growth monitoring.

  • Under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme in India, Anganwadi workers monitor child growth using growth charts that are based on the WHO Child Growth Standards (2006).
  • These are incorporated into the Mother and Child Protection (MCP) Card, which tracks weight-for-age for boys and girls from birth to 5 years.
  • The aim is to identify growth faltering early and take corrective action.
  • Previously, some states used the Modified Road to Health Chart (MRHC), but the current national standard is the WHO-based MCP card.

Explanation of other options:

NCHS (Option A): Based on US National Center for Health Statistics data; previously used in India but replaced by WHO standards in 2006.

IAP (Option B): Indian Academy of Pediatrics charts are used mainly for clinical and school health purposes, not by Anganwadi workers.

CDC (Option D): US Centers for Disease Control growth charts, relevant for American populations, not used in ICDS growth monitoring.

A tablet containing 20 mg elemental iron & 100 µg folic acid weekly for children under 5
A tablet containing 100 mg elemental iron & 500 µg folic acid biweekly for adults
A tablet containing 45 mg elemental iron & 400 µg folic acid biweekly for children aged 6-10 years

questions.text: According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat strategy, which of the following correctly represents prophylactic IFA supplementation for adolescent girls and boys (10-19 years)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adolescents (10-19 years) receive one blue IFA tablet weekly, containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 µg folic acid, under the current national program.

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program (under the broader National Iron Plus Initiative) delivers age-specific iron-folic acid prophylaxis using different formulations and frequencies for optimal efficacy.
  • Here's the updated age-wise dosing schedule

These regimens ensure coverage across the life cycle, effectively preventing both nutritional anemia and its long-term consequences.

choices.text: Sips of water, especially in summer season

questions.text: A 3-month-old healthy infant is brought for a routine check-up. The mother has been exclusively breastfeeding but is concerned that the baby might need additional fluids or supplements during the summer season. According to current national and WHO guidelines, what should be given in addition to breast milk during the first 6 months of life?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months meets all nutritional and hydration needs, even in hot climates.

  • WHO and the Government of India recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of life - meaning the infant receives only breast milk, without any additional water, fluids, or complementary foods.
  • Breast milk contains the perfect balance of nutrients, antibodies, and adequate water to maintain hydration, even during hot summer months.
  • Introducing other liquids or solids early can increase the risk of infections, interfere with nutrient absorption, and reduce breast milk intake.
  • Routine iron supplementation is not recommended for term healthy infants before 6 months unless there are specific risk factors (e.g., low birth weight, preterm birth).
  • Complementary feeding with mashed vegetables, pulses, and other solids should begin after 6 completed months, along with continued breastfeeding.
  • Breast milk alone is enough to prevent dehydration; extra water may introduce pathogens and reduce milk intake.

questions.text: The protective effects of breast milk are attributed to which of the following components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breast milk contains immune factors like IgA, lysozymes, and macrophages that provide passive immunity to the infant.

  • Breast milk, especially colostrum, is rich in immune components that protect infants against infections during early life when their immune system is still developing.
  • Secretory IgA binds to pathogens on mucosal surfaces, preventing their attachment to epithelial cells.
  • Lysozymes have antibacterial action by breaking down bacterial cell walls, particularly Gram-positive bacteria.
  • Macrophages present in breast milk are active immune cells that can phagocytose pathogens and produce cytokines.
  • Together, these factors reduce the incidence of gastrointestinal, respiratory, and ear infections in breastfed infants, contributing to lower infant morbidity and mortality

questions.text: Identify the type of desk given in the image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A minus-type desk is designed so that the seat height is lower than the desk height by more than the recommended ergonomic difference, causing a downward arm position.

  • In school health and ergonomics, desks are classified into plus type, minus type, and zero type based on the vertical relationship between the seat and desk height.
  • In a minus-type desk, the seat is placed too low relative to the desk height, forcing the student to raise their arms to write.
  • This posture increases strain on the shoulders and neck, can contribute to fatigue, and may negatively affect spinal posture over time.
  • School health programs often recommend zero-type desks for optimal ergonomics, where the desk height is at the ideal level relative to the seat.
  • The plus-type desk is too low relative to the seat, forcing a stooping posture.

questions.text: ICDS does not cover which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ICDS provides pre-school non-formal education but does not provide formal schooling.

  • The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme delivers a package of early childhood care and development services through Anganwadi centres, including supplementary nutrition, health check-ups, referral services, immunization linkages, and non-formal pre-school education.
  • It aims to improve health, nutrition, and development in children under 6 years and to provide support to pregnant and lactating mothers.
  • Formal (curriculum-based) education and regular school instruction are outside the ICDS mandate and fall under the formal education system.
  • Nutritional supplementation is provided through Anganwadi centres as a core ICDS service. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anganwadi workers provide nutrition and health counselling to mothers/families. (Option C ruled out)
  • Immunization is a part of ICDS activities in collaboration with health departments; Anganwadi centres help facilitate immunization. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: ½ of calorie and ½ of daily protein requirement
½ of calorie and 1/3 of daily protein requirement
1/3 of calorie and ½ of daily protein requirement
1/3 of calorie and 1/3 of daily protein requirement

questions.text: As per nutrition guidelines, the Mid-day School Meal should provide what proportion of the daily calorie and protein requirement of a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Mid-day Meal Scheme aims to provide 1/3 of daily calorie needs and ½ of daily protein needs for school-going children.

  • The Mid-day Meal Scheme is designed to improve the nutritional status of school children, enhance school attendance, and foster social equity.
  • As per norms, each mid-day meal should contribute at least 1/3 of the total daily energy requirement and ½ of the daily protein requirement of a child, based on age-specific nutritional needs.
  • For comparison - ICDS nutritional norms:
    • In the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program for children aged 1-6 years, the supplementary nutrition provided at Anganwadi centres should meet ½ of the daily protein requirement and 1/3 of the daily calorie requirement.

questions.text: Match the type of child care/reform institution with the correct description or scenario:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Remand homes handle juveniles in conflict with the law, borstals train older difficult boys, orphanages house children under care, and foster homes provide temporary family-based care.

  • Remand Home (A-2)
    • An institution where juveniles awaiting trial or disposition are kept under supervision.
    • The example of the 14-year-old boy caught shoplifting fits here.
    • Focus: temporary detention, counseling, and basic education.
  • Borstal (B-1)
    • Special reformatory schools for boys over 16 years who are difficult to handle in certified schools.
    • They receive training, discipline, and reformation over ~3 years.
  • Orphanage (C-3)
    • A residential institution for children without parents or guardians.
    • Often under medical and psychiatric supervision.
  • Foster Home (D-4)
    • Family-based temporary care for children whose parents are unable to care for them.
    • Aim: nurture in a home-like setting until reintegration or adoption.
  • Other similar child welfare/reform institutions:
    • Certified Schools: Long-term institutional care for delinquent children under court orders.
    • Observation Homes: Short-term intake and observation before placement in remand homes or other institutions.
    • Special Homes: For juveniles convicted under the Juvenile Justice Act.
    • Aftercare Organisations: Assist juveniles after release from institutional care to reintegrate into society.
